#Text=THE TELESCOPE OF THE ROCKY MOUNTAINS

#Text=On the 20th of October in the preceding year , after the close of the subscription , the president of the Gun Club had credited the Observatory of Cambridge with the necessary sums for the construction of a gigantic optical instrument .
#Text=This instrument was designed for the purpose of rendering visible on the surface of the moon any object exceeding nine feet in diameter .
#Text=At the period when the Gun Club essayed their great experiment , such instruments had reached a high degree of perfection , and produced some magnificent results .
#Text=Two telescopes in particular , at this time , were possessed of remarkable power and of gigantic dimensions .
#Text=The first , constructed by Herschel , was thirty-six feet in length , and had an object-glass of four feet six inches ; it possessed a magnifying power of 6,000 .
#Text=The second was raised in Ireland , in Parsonstown Park , and belongs to Lord Rosse .

#Text=The length of this tube is forty-eight feet , and the diameter of its object-glass six feet ; it magnifies 6,400 times , and required an immense erection of brick work and masonry for the purpose of working it , its weight being twelve and a half tons .

#Text=Still , despite these colossal dimensions , the actual enlargements scarcely exceeded 6,000 times in round numbers ; consequently , the moon was brought within no nearer an apparent distance than thirty-nine miles ; and objects of less than sixty feet in diameter , unless they were of very considerable length , were still imperceptible .

#Text=In the present case , dealing with a projectile nine feet in diameter and fifteen feet long , it became necessary to bring the moon within an apparent distance of five miles at most ; and for that purpose to establish a magnifying power of 48,000 times .
#Text=Such was the question proposed to the Observatory of Cambridge , There was no lack of funds ; the difficulty was purely one of construction .
#Text=After considerable discussion as to the best form and principle of the proposed instrument the work was finally commenced .
#Text=According to the calculations of the Observatory of Cambridge , the tube of the new reflector would require to be 280 feet in length , and the object-glass sixteen feet in diameter .
#Text=Colossal as these dimensions may appear , they were diminutive in comparison with the 10,000 foot telescope proposed by the astronomer Hooke only a few years ago !
#Text=Regarding the choice of locality , that matter was promptly determined .
#Text=The object was to select some lofty mountain , and there are not many of these in the United States .
#Text=In fact there are but two chains of moderate elevation , between which runs the magnificent Mississippi , the " king of rivers " as these Republican Yankees delight to call it .
#Text=Eastwards rise the Appalachians , the very highest point of which , in New Hampshire , does not exceed the very moderate altitude of 5,600 feet .

#Text=On the west , however , rise the Rocky Mountains , that immense range which , commencing at the Straights of Magellan , follows the western coast of Southern America under the name of the Andes or the Cordilleras , until it crosses the Isthmus of Panama , and runs up the whole of North America to the very borders of the Polar Sea .
#Text=The highest elevation of this range still does not exceed 10,700 feet .

#Text=With this elevation , nevertheless , the Gun Club were compelled to be content , inasmuch as they had determined that both telescope and Columbiad should be erected within the limits of the Union .
#Text=All the necessary apparatus was consequently sent on to the summit of Long 's Peak , in the territory of Missouri .
#Text=Neither pen nor language can describe the difficulties of all kinds which the American engineers had to surmount , of the prodigies of daring and skill which they accomplished .

#Text=They had to raise enormous stones , massive pieces of wrought iron , heavy corner-clamps and huge portions of cylinder , with an object-glass weighing nearly 30,000 pounds , above the line of perpetual snow for more than 10,000 feet in height , after crossing desert prairies , impenetrable forests , fearful rapids , far from all centers of population , and in the midst of savage regions , in which every detail of life becomes an almost insoluble problem .
#Text=And yet , notwithstanding these innumerable obstacles , American genius triumphed .
#Text=In less than a year after the commencement of the works , toward the close of September , the gigantic reflector rose into the air to a height of 280 feet .

#Text=It was raised by means of an enormous iron crane ; an ingenious mechanism allowed it to be easily worked toward all the points of the heavens , and to follow the stars from the one horizon to the other during their journey through the heavens .
#Text=It had cost $ 400,000 .
#Text=The first time it was directed toward the moon the observers evinced both curiosity and anxiety .
#Text=What were they about to discover in the field of this telescope which magnified objects 48,000 times ?
#Text=Would they perceive peoples , herds of lunar animals , towns , lakes , seas ?
#Text=No ! there was nothing which science had not already discovered ! and on all the points of its disc the volcanic nature of the moon became determinable with the utmost precision .
#Text=But the telescope of the Rocky Mountains , before doing its duty to the Gun Club , rendered immense services to astronomy .

#Text=Thanks to its penetrative power , the depths of the heavens were sounded to the utmost extent ; the apparent diameter of a great number of stars was accurately measured ; and Mr. Clark , of the Cambridge staff , resolved the Crab nebula in Taurus , which the reflector of Lord Rosse had never been able to decompose .
